[h1] REVIEW [/h1]

 GRAV is a good game. I open with that statement as, unfortunately, the game is hanging around the 60% positive review mark, which, in Steam terms, is terrible.

 Does the game deserve negative reviews? Yes, of course, every game will have people who dislike it, and that's fine.
But does the game deserve THIS MANY negative reviews? No, I wouldn't say so. GRAV isn't a bad game, and you will notice from most of the negative reviews that people who dislike this game are people who have only played the game for a few hours, or people who complain about how the servers aren't fully alive and active all the time. That is because these people do not fit into the target audience.

 I will address all of these subjective "flaws", but first I will point out to you that GRAV has a LOT of grinding. This is not necessarily a bad thing, even though the general public would assume so. The game is absolutely FULL of things to work for, and many of these things take a very long time to achieve. In my opinion, this is a great thing. You always have something on the horizon to strive for, you'll always be able to try out that new equipment you just earned, and you'll always, [i]always[/i] feel satisfied with the results of a long grind. That is why you should take another perspective on any review with under 10 hours played.

 As for server activity, PvP, etcetera, I don't recommend this game if you're looking for a purely player-versus-player experience against random people. GRAV isn't built for that. A few experience levels make a huge imbalance in damage and total health, and so the game doesn't hit the mark as far as public PvP environments go.
If PvE isn't your thing, though, don't be strayed away! I think GRAV is great as a team game, where everyone starts at the same time and has a race to the top, in some sort of red vs blue scenario.

 But, where this game really shines for me, is with or against friends. Progression is made much sweeter when you have a partner or two by your side, so I recommend this game the most to those who favour PvE or team environments. GRAV has so much to offer in terms of fun player interaction, and memorable moments are a plenty. I've had many epic experiences gliding through the air alongside my small group, riding a futuristic vehicle over plains, or simply dancing around a fire with friends.

 So, in conclusion, I can easily recommend GRAV. It is fun and it is good. However, you should take some more time to consider if you are wanting to play the game alone. That can be said for a lot of multiplayer-compatible games, but GRAV in particular shines with friends.

TL;DR: Should have returned this game instead of looking for the good in it. Does not match advertisement or expectations. Several environments in preview videos do not exist. Previews suggest gameplay that is not present in current stage of development. Gameplay is exceedingly simplistic grinding for numbers. Game is in alpha stages with resource, stability, and memory leak issues. Potential exists, but no amount of quantity makes up for the lack of quality.

What follows is a section by section commentary on the "about this game" bullet points.

Endless Worlds - Planets are not procedurally generated, counter to advertisement. All planets have a static map. Exoplanets rotate every 3 hours, making some game objects virtually useless. Exoplanets are often either small enough or with rough terrain to render land vehicles near useless. Flying vehicles feature six axis movement but no horizon or flight hud and no tuneable flight controls: expect to roll and tumble wildly for your first dozen flights. Glide suit and jetpack do not work together, you must alternate using one and the other to remain in the air.

Gorgeous Visuals - While GRAV can be rather pretty, the visuals are unoptimised. The game itself consumes an inordinate amount of system RAM (4gb+) and leaks memory (consumed 7gb system ram after a few hours). Reducing texture LOD reduces visual quality far faster than system load. I frequently experienced terrible artifacting near the beach area, with each patch to the game slightly altering the location and severity of the artifacting.

Frenzied Combat - Circle strafe while tapping backwards and holding the fire button for up to a minute per enemy. Twelve different palatte swapping enemies advance with the same mindless behavior and ignore collision with most player placed objects, but halt and become confused when the player jumps onto slightly elevated or out of the way platforms. Enemy melee attacks damage the player for ~50% of health in early game and nearly nothing late game. Rare enemies use mild but irritating camera shake inducing ranged attacks alternating with AoE ground pounds and regular melee. One mob has a pushback that deals significant damage if you are pushed into a wall. "Boss" type enemies are ~3x the size with ~4x the health and ~2x the XP. Using on-tier equipment against equal-level mobs, players damage enemies for ~1% of health using automatic weapons: expect to carry 10,000 rounds of ammunition and use 75-150 rounds per mob. Grind away for hours as XP gain sharply falls toward 10 when fighting mobs below your level and damage sharply falls toward 1 when fighting mobs above your level. Enjoy becoming stuck on random terrain or ambushed by sudden respawns from behind and dropping 50-90% of your loot.

Player vs Player - No easily managed friends list: become friends with people by giving them the numeric passcode to your team's private chat and granting them entry to all your buildings and belongings. No method to determine who is currently using that passcode. Changing your individual passcode does not automatically update your buildings or chests. No such thing as a list of foes for tracking your enemies. No such thing as a neutral list, anyone who isn't your friend is your enemy. Impossible to raid other players bases unless they contain one of two different placeable objects.

Play With Friends - Most of my friends were bored within 10 hours. Many quit after 60. Due to the nature of the friend passcode, it is very difficult to make friends for fear of major theft. System resource requirement is prohibitive to running a Solo or local server.

Powerful Base Construction - Build cube shaped rooms to make cube shaped bases. No method to control which walls are removed or preserved when building an adjoining room. No method to add walls back to a room after walls have been removed. Destroy the entire room and try again. Sometimes this requires you to destroy an entire quarter of a base and try again. Don't bother trying to build balconies around your base. Turret damage is overpowered at low levels and near worthless at upper levels.

Extensive Crafting - There are ~123 different crafting materials, but the bulk of work is done by 10. The rest are one-off items for specific recipes you may use only once or never at all. You will craft an AR and an SMG because the AR has the best DPS without rapid clicking and the SMG ammo drops are plentiful enough to make it a viable secondary. All other ammunition is a waste of inventory space. By the time you have an automatic weapon, melee is a waste of time and effort. Equipment progresses linearly while costs increase somewhat exponentially. Defensive equipment is the primary progression, but variation is lacking. At least one set of equipment is a palette swap. Defending against an environmental hazard often means using equipment well below the area's difficulty. There is no method to sort, filter, or easily manage your inventory or your storage bins.

Dynamic Environmental Events - Enemies spawn more frequently at night. Night is very dark and flashlights are craftable temporary accessories. Large numbers of a single enemy type will spawn occasionally as an "event". I have never seen flowers bloom as part of the day/night cycle as advertised. I have never seen meteors fall across the terrain as advertised, let alone regular rain. Sometimes there is fog, and that's about it.

Procedurally Generated Dungeons - Dungeons are procedurally generated from about sixteen different component rooms, but component rooms are static, uninteresting tunnels, often accompanied by invisible clip walls and enemy pathing issues. The same four direct harvestable resources are available on all planets. Three resources require a placeable object to create/harvest. Four resources are exoplanet specific, making them slightly harder to get. Each "level" of exoplanet has an "uncommon" variation of each of these resources, but you'll soon find yourself throwing out stacks and stacks of the uncommons once you've used them for their one purpose. Sometimes there is a pit in the caves or the procedural generation makes a gap to empty space; I guess those are the advertised environmental obstacles.

Hostile Environments - Warping to a planet with a hostile environment without the appropriate equipment begins a countdown. When the countdown is over, you lose 5% of your max health every "tick". All water off the home planet is damaging. That's about it.

Roadmap - Several of these features are already or partially implemented. This is not a good track of coming features or completed features.

The main menu is minimal however the ingame HUD works fairly well. An upside is the inclusion of item descriptions in the HUD, making learning the game a bit easier.

[i]Gameplay 4/5[/i]
Gameplay is comprised of multiple components:
[list]
[*]The Gather
[*]The Grind
[*]The Build
[*]The Reward
[/list]

[u]The Gather[/u]
Resource gathering is primarily done through the use of a 'multitool'. This device allows you to effectively deconstruct resources into nuggets. Currently the primary resouces are: Ore, Wood, Fossil, Food, Element-X.
The first 3 spawn in random locations on the map, dependant on the biome. Food is available via a 'Farm' which requires wood for 'fuel'. Element-X however is a little trickier, it requires a harvester to be built and placed on to a deposit. This must then be checked and emptied. All resources are available as drops from mobs/lootboxes, aswell as materials.

[u]The Grind[/u]
Love it or hate it, the Grind is a key component of any levelling game. Thats right, GRAV has levels. Firstly, lets look at the way the world is layed out. There are multiple 'biomes' which are all assigned with a 'state' and a mob level. For example, you may start in a lush forest, where the 'state' is freezing and the level is 1-2. This means that there is tonnes of wood at your disposal, the mobs do freezing damage and are of course level 1-2.
As per any levelling scheme, low level creatures only give good experience until you equal their level, then you are best to chase bigger prey.
What I like about the levelling system in GRAV is that the mobs are genuinely brutal. At level 6, if you try and take on a medium bugdog of level 8 - its practically a deathwish. Unless you have decent gear and lots of health packs.
Lootwise, grinding is the only way you will get blueprints - required to further your knowledge, build more stuff and win at life.
[b]sidenote-[/b] I forgot to mention the excellently done combat system. Although simple, for an Alpha game, it is smooth and well polished whilst maintaining fast paced combat.

[u]The Build[/u]
By grinding and gathering, you are able to get materials and resources. As you would expect from any sandbox game, these are used to build/craft things.
Building is simple, there are a number of predetermined layouts, which allow you to build in a modular fashion. The interface is decent and the skill required is minimal. In terms of craft items and machines, there is a natural progression here which allows you to build bigger and better things. However, the most vital component is blueprints, which once aquired allow you to build items such as Generators and Automated Turrets.

[u]The Reward[/u]
This is where it all ties together and SOMEHOW GRAV has kept a very balanced gameplay. In order to build decent items, you need decent mats which can only be found on decent foes. And thus the circle is born. Although not disimilar to the multitudes of sandbox games available, GRAV just seems right. There is just enough annoying resource gathering wihtout it becoming a bore.


[b]Summary 10/15[/b]
At the end of the day, its an Alpha. There are issues, bugs and bugdogs. There is no single player, besides running your own lonely server. The netcode is laggy and and the system requirements are pretty brutal.

However,
Its fun, exciting, progressive, rich and adventurous. The combat is great, grinding is fun and with a blueprint system, you need to keep searching for your next leap of knowledge.

My tips to starting with GRAV : 
Check your system specs before purchase.
Ensure you have friends to play with, or at least plan on playing with other people.
If the game bunks out when you run it for the first time - dont panic. goto the discussion boards and search.

Hope you enjoy GRAV!
